text: I do not know what the doubling effect is, but for optimal performance and to debug the dynamic focus I recommend the following:

elements.text: I do not know what the doubling effect is, but for optimal performance and to debug the dynamic focus I recommend the following:

text:
• Use one sheet from one side, instead of 3.
• Make absolutely sure that your sheet waist is where the software thinks it is. To test this, use the highest NA possible with all of the same setttings, but do NOT use dynamic focus. There are two methods to check the position of the waist in your sample:
    ◦ Take a relatively thin stack and then look at an XZ view. You should see the region of highest axial resolution in the middle. If not, you need to adjust your sheetmotor calibration
    ◦ While looking at the sample live, move the sample position up and down. If you have a very high sheet NA and a sample with a lot of structure you should see a narrow band of changes centered where the wasit is. If that is not centered in the middle of the field of view; adjust your sheetmotor calibration
Once you know that the hardware alignment is perfect, the next step is to figure out what is causing the doubling. Is it the algorithm, or is it something in the hardware? I recommend you try the following:

Make absolutely sure that your sheet waist is where the software thinks it is. To test this, use the highest NA possible with all of the same setttings, but do NOT use dynamic focus. There are two methods to check the position of the waist in your sample:
Take a relatively thin stack and then look at an XZ view. You should see the region of highest axial resolution in the middle. If not, you need to adjust your sheetmotor calibration

While looking at the sample live, move the sample position up and down. If you have a very high sheet NA and a sample with a lot of structure you should see a narrow band of changes centered where the wasit is. If that is not centered in the middle of the field of view; adjust your sheetmotor calibration

Once you know that the hardware alignment is perfect, the next step is to figure out what is causing the doubling. Is it the algorithm, or is it something in the hardware? I recommend you try the following:

text:
• Take a stack with the DF mode on in blend mode, but click the option to get the raw data. This will create a lot of data (so maybe do a thinner stack), but you will be able to see if there is doubling in the raw, unprocessed data, and compare to LaVision's algorithm
• Repeat the same but with the contrast enhancement mode.
The more general question is how to push the system to its limits in terms of resolution. Unfortunately, in a region packed with cells (like CA1) this gets very tricky. I've estimated the resolution using dynamic focus with the zoom body configuration at a zoom of 5X, with 0.5um silica beads and it is roughly 1um in XY and 4um in Z. These are very rough numbers but you can see that if your cells are very crowded it is going to get very hard.

I can't comment on whether the infinity corrected optics have significantly better resolution as I have never tried them.

(Formatting point: sorry for all of the breaks in my response; I keep doing ENTER instead of SHIFT-ENTER)

If you need more advice, send me an email and we can do a zoom.

text: Thanks Pablo for all the precise insights. I had not seen the doubling issue before on the UM2 system with infinity corrected optics, but I am now testing the DF on the 2 new Blaze systems we just received, and 1 of the 2 systems has that issue. I noticed that the issue is not uniform on the field of view, meaning that the doubling would be on 1 side of the frame only. More puzzling, the doubling is not in the same y position across different planes, and some z planes don't have it at all. The fact that only 1 microscope of the 2 new systems has the issue makes me think that this could be a miscalibration between the software and hardware, although we are very careful to center the light sheet focus as Pablo is explaining above. I'll contact Miltenyi and report back here if we can fix the issue.
